Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of Unreliable Input on Children' s Acquisition of Spanish

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Children acquire a linguistic system in a short amount of time and with no great apparent effort. This is a hard task made much harder by the fact that children are exposed to a high degree of variation. For example, no two words are ever pronounced exactly the same way. There is variation across dialects, as well as intra- and inter-speaker variability that can be linked to socio-economic status, gender, etc. Most research on language acquisition has either assumed that the language the child is exposed to is not variable or has modeled input variability either computationally or in a small-scale laboratory setting. This project will examine the effects of input variability on the acquisition of plural morphology in two dialects of Spanish. Chilean Spanish has a socio-linguistically conditioned phonological process which masks the realization of plural morphology, but Mexico City Spanish does not. By studying how children acquire plural markers in a natural setting, researchers will be able to determine how (un)reliable input affects the acquisition process and also what sorts of input data are relevant to the child who is building her own internalized grammatical system.

The comparison of the acquisition process in these two varieties of Spanish can be used as a testing ground for various hypotheses about the ways in which the learning mechanism interacts with the input data. These studies will provide much needed data which will contribute to a better understanding of the influence of dialect variation on children's early language development. Dialect variation must be taken into consideration when evaluating children's performance in the context of standardized testing, teaching strategies and clinical intervention in the case of speech disorders. Approximately 300 hours of transcribed speech will be made available to other researchers via a computer searchable database concerning the development of plural morphology in children who are exposed to dialects where the plural suffix is omitted to various degrees. These data can then be used by speech pathologists to design dialect-sensitive tests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to examine how sociolinguistic variation interacts with language development in children. In particular, we studied acquisition of the plural marker /-s/ in two varieties of Spanish. In Chilean Spanish there is a phonological process whereby syllable-final /s/ is reduced to an aspiration or an omission (e.g. the Spanish word gatos (‘cats’) can be pronounced as [gatos], [gatoh], or [gato]). This process is constrained by linguistic (e.g. inflection, phonological context) and sociolinguistic (e.g. gender, age, SES) constraints and affects the production of the plural marker because sometimes it is pronounced by adult speakers (as [s] or [h]) and sometimes it is omitted. This means that Chilean children are exposed to a variable input for plural marking. We asked whether this variable production of the plural marker affects Chilean children’s acquisition of the plural marker. We compare acquisition in Chilean children to Mexican children (from Mexico City) because in the latter dialect the plural marker is always pronounced as [-s] and is not aspirated or omitted. By comparing acquisition of the plural marker in these two dialects of Spanish we are able to examine how differences in the input (i.e., production of the plural marker by caregivers) affects children’s acquisition of it. This allows us to hypothesize about language processes more generally because it provides a window for determining how the child language learner interacts with the linguistic input (i.e., language of her caregivers) to acquire the native language.

            To address these questions we used NSF funding to create a large child language corpus of Chilean caregivers and their children in free play activities (Miller & Schmitt Chilean Child Language Corpus) so that we could examine the use of /s/ lenition in the caregivers’ speech. We also assessed each child on their knowledge of the plural marker through a number of production and comprehension tasks. The results of this project indicate that Chilean caregivers omit the plural marker in the speech to their children while Mexican caregivers do not and that there is no difference in omission rates when caregivers speak to their children vs. when they speak to other adults; however, we are still investigating this latter finding. The results also indicate that Chilean children are variable in production of /s/ from the earliest stages – they produce the full [s] form as well as aspiration and omissions – yet they take longer than Mexican children to associate the plural marker [-s] to a more-than-one interpretation. Analyses of data are still underway and further results will be reported as they are published.

            This study will contribute to a better understanding of the influence of dialect variation on children’s early language development. These differences have to be taken into consideration when evaluating children’s performance in the context of standardized testing, teaching strategies and clinical intervention in the case of speech disorders. Plural morphology has been suggested as one possible characteristic for diagnosing Specific Language Impairment in Spanish-speaking children. Unfortunately, this previous research only examined Mexican Spanish-speaking children. If we consider Chilean and also Cuban, Puerto Rican and Dominican Spanish, much more care has to be taken, since plural morphology omission is very common in these dialects. Our studies will provide much needed data concerning the development of plural morphology in children who are exposed to dialects where plural is omitted to various degrees and can be used to design dialect sensitive tests.
